title: Has anyone healed from narcissistic abuse just by reading Quora answers? - Quora

response.answer_text: Has anyone healed from narcissistic abuse just by reading Quora answers? Hell no! What Quora did do was help me validate what I was dealing with. Thanks to my bud, Bassel C! His words with what I was searching for at the time when I needed the right words to describe what I was going through? (Boom) Bassel! For some odd reason when I was looking up the word superiority on Google? I came across the word “Narcissism” and didn’t think much of it at first but what I saw was right in front of my face. The answers to what I needed to know, were right there for me to see. “Which hurts because I knew what I was dealing with will never work” “A Covert Narcissist” As far as healing from Quora? No, this site has given me new light and more information on Narcissism/Narcy/Narcissist/Narc/Narcopath any of these names has helped me move on. What I do seek is a psychiatrist/therapist and talk about this shitty abuse to my new helper. She’s giving me insight on how to grow from this crappy relationship. What Quora does do for me. I share my stories through certain questions and I also try and help others get a better understanding of Narcissistic abuse. If there’s anyone out there struggling with their relationships? I try and help them get out of Hell and into a better place of understanding. Help them heal. I’m full of great energy and I want to help others escape Hell. Hell sucks! Quora is a great place to write your pain and get it out of you no matter how it sounds. People need to hear this stuff. It’s not fun seeing your soul rot away over some jerk who never loved you. They’re only in it to use and abuse you. So, has Quora help me heal from narcissistic abuse? No, it has not! It’s therapeutic for me to write. That’s about it! Oh, I get to meet some of the best people on the planet! That’s the best part about this site! So many awesome amazing souls are right here. Much love to all of you! Your fellow Quoran, Dane Staton!

Has anyone healed from narcissistic abuse just by reading Quora answers? Thanks for the A2A. I can't really answer for everyone else, but I can tell you how Quora has helped me. I literally stumbled upon Quora about a year ago. I had some pretty bad relationships… all mental, psychological, emotional crap. For years I thought I was the problem. My first experience with a narcissist was in 2006, I married him. We were together for about 3 years, we have a child together, I had a son from a previous relationship, but I had never had a relationship like that one. And because of my low self-esteem and low self confidence I just thought I wasn't trying hard enough. I had a couple of really bad relationships after that that were somewhat similar to that marriage. I did not know anything about narcissism other than hearing the word on crime shows on TV every now and then. The first time I heard of Quora was through an email from Quora. I had no idea what it was so I skipped over the email and went about my day, but I kept kind of wandering what this Quora thing was. A couple weeks later, I got another email from Quora, and this one had a question-and-answer on it. I don't remember which question it was but I remember reading it and going, ”Huh, maybe I should check this Quora thing out.” When I got home from work that day, I opened Quora and I started reading…and I started to realize that the confusing, chaotic relationships that I had were not one of a kind. After reading many, many answers that correlated so closely with what happened to me, I was pretty intrigued. It wasn't until that time that I realized that it didn't matter how hard I tried, it never would have been enough. And let's be honest, I'm not going to say that I never started any fights, I'm not going to say that I never argued back, I'm not going to say that I was perfect by any means, but what I can say is that I was confused, I was frustrated, I was lost. All the while I was trying to heal from a bad relationship, I finally, through Quora, discovered that the hurt I have been trying to heal went much deeper than what I had ever realized. Being on Quora has taught me so much. I finally learned about what I was trying to heal from. Being able to read stories from other people who completely understood what I had been through was literally a Godsend. I'm not completely healed, but i don’t think that we ever completely heal. I never went to counseling, which I probably should have, but in learning that I wasn't alone, it gave me a greater understanding of what I had gone through. Reading advice and stories and revelations from other narcissistic abuse victims, gave me the confidence to start sharing parts of my own story. In doing so I began helping other people…which is something I've always wanted to do anyway. So can one be healed from narcissistic abuse simply through Quora? I don't know if you can ever be 100% healed, but being able to read and share stories, and learning that other people have lived through this too... that other people completely understand your chaos makes it a lot easier to deal with. The last 13 years of my life have been chaos, but in the last year I've been able to answer more of my own questions about what happened, and I've been able to make a lot more sense of parts of my life. God bless, ~Robyn

Of course not. Quora will help your for the first few steps only. Quora fulfill mainly the first few OH SO IMPORTANT STEPS on the road for recovery. 1- VALIDATION Yes it really happened. You are not crazy, what you think you saw or partially remembered wad really there. You where betrayed my dear, more then you can even imagine at the moment. (the whole picture will appear over time, when you are ready) 2- He/she will never change (this one need many many many repetitions :) 3- It’s not only you. It happened to me, Martin, Sophie, Paul, Claudia, Veronica, Maude, Stewart, Rain, Sara, Stephen, Bev, Anjela, Mark, Christine, Bassel, Pathy ……etc….. etc……. 4- Being free to express anger, disgust, frustration, and puzzlement. No no no, don’t try to explain yourself with the narcissist. Anyway we all know you tried already. Tell me, did it work? Usually, it takes hundreds, or thousands of repetitions so the brain slowly start to “get it” and disconnect from “narcland”. Quora play’s the very important role of repeating the same things over and over again with different words and in different forms, different peoples, different styles, over and over again until you start trusting your own judgment, your own impressions, emotions and feelings. And from that solid base, you can choose to start healing. When you feel validated enough, then you can decide to begin the road for recovery….. either alone, or with a good friend, or with a therapist (don’t talk about narcissism, just describe the abuse) or my second favorite approach; with a coach (tons of them on youtube, choose a style you like, and contact them) or …. my personal favorite, with workbooks like “You Can Thrive After Abuse from” Melanie Tonia Evans” or “Codependent Now What?” from Lisa A Romano or “I Miss Me...and I Want Me Back!! ” from Michelle Nieve. So…… many possible roads for healing, but none of this could possible without the Oh! So important phase of validation and confirmation of the abuse. After a while, you will see most people go forward and start living again…… UPTDATE 10 september 2019: After reading about 80 books on the topic, the best by far is The Betrayal Bond by Patrick J Carnes. So my recommended healing kit would be: (for serious, motivated healers only) 1- The Betrayal Bond: Braking Free of Exploitative Relationships from Patrick J Carnes Free preview here The Betrayal Bond 2- Boundaries after a pathological relationship Adelyne Birch 3- Complex PTSD: From Surviving to Thriving by Pete Walker Good luck kind souls and me God bless you along the road. ♥♥♥

I have jokingly replied in some of my answers that I didn’t realize the poster was married to my wife. Some Quorans experiences mirror my own so very close. And that is what Quora does. It simply lets us be in touch with others who have been through the same experiences. My ex like many others, smeared me hard. She accused me of just about anything one can imagine short of physical abuse. To be able to talk with others, to learn that I am believed and to know that I am not alone, is nothing short of amazing when one is trying to heal. As we know a narcissist wants to isolate us, and control us. I’m a big guy, ex was a diminutive blonde. Who was ever going to believe me over all her accusations? I had so many flying monkey’s swarming around, I needed a 10 foot swatter to keep them at bay. But experts don’t tell you about ‘love bombing’ and flying monkey’s and smears and gaslighting and Grey Rock and discarded. That information comes from people who have been down in the trenches. From those people who helped me understand what bus flattened me. Just from Quora…. no. But I am healing because of Quora! I am proud to be a Narcissistic Survivor from Quora!

I can't say that I've been healed on here. Healing is in your own mind and it's something you have to do for yourself. But on here, I have found all the answers that I need to explain why I feel the way I do. On here, has taken away some of that guilty I'm to blame feelings that I had. from this site, I now understand why mutual people look at me as if I'm crazy based off of what the narc has told them. I could never figure out why people that I don't even know, had such negative vibes towards me. It also has allowed me to know what's coming from the narc. And believe me, it's the same repetitive crap all the time. This site has allowed me to say what I feel instead of keeping it all bottled up for fear of retaliation from the narc. The best thing about this site, is that I'm not alone. My narc made me feel like I was the only person in the world that thought he was a piece of s***. That my morals were somehow screwed up. That everyone knew I was crazy but me, and that they were all laughing at me because they weren't my friends. It makes you become very attached to the narc when you feel that the world's against you. And that's exactly what they go for. Complete and total dominating control.

I was in an abusive narcissistic relationship for 20+ years. I have seen the devil himself in the last 8 months… For me, I became stronger but immediately sought out a therapist and friends for constant support. I kept a journal to reread to make sure I wasn’t losing my mind. I kept trying to detach from the quickest way I knew how and his lack of control made him furious! The more you keep taking away, the more you can gain your self esteem and not have to deal with power plays. I am no contact with him. I was somewhat guarded but was motivated to keep running from him. I am in a new relationship with a man who cares for me, enjoys doing things with me…. No games, no power struggle, no guilt…and have the groundwork supportive of a great new beginning. I was blind to the control in my marriage. But I feel so light and free now. So I guess I can say I am healed..

The first step to healing properly from narcissistic abuse is recognizing that you have been abused by a narcissistic person. That light bulb moment comes when you suddenly read your own story in someone else’s words. Another part of healing is receiving validation for your experience. Another part is finding support. Another part is receiving the gift of being able to help and support others that have suffered similarly. Quora offers all of these. They can be found elsewhere too.

It does help when you come across people who have had similar experiences. Narcissistic abuse makes you question your own reality as you are gaslighted again and again.. When you interact with other survivors by reading their questions/answers, you realize that you were not crazy what narcissist wanted you to believe about yourself. Quora does help, any kind of help is always a plus.. I never feel spending time on Quora was waste of my time.. It has helped me a lot..

Not exactly healed just by reading Quora answers. But I have learned enough that I was able to go No Contact, and more or less stick with it. Not just Quora, also HG Tudor, Sam Vaknin, and some others. It’s an extremely complicated set of issues, because there are at least two people involved, both with their own issues, and the relationship adds to the complexity. Every day I read a little bit, and reflect on what I read, and draw strength from it.

Haha, this is a great question. I think the sharing of information and experiences is crucial to the healing process—and that’s what Quora offers in full. Hopefully, combined with in-person connections and maybe some counselling, people will move through a healing process that may have started with Quora.

Not healed as such, more so providing a platform to understanding the hell with which I was going through. Reading about experiences others have had so similar to my own provided an insight into steps I needed to take in order to become the person I was before but a stronger version of myself. It also provided valuable information of what to expect, as they say “forewarned is forearmed”. In order to heal I needed to love myself first, surround myself with happiness and a good support network. I allow myself to be free without oppression. Life is to be lived not be held down by a selfish individual. Love and light x

No, but indirectly yes. Quora has been a revelation to me. This is the only place I have felt other people truly understand what I'm going through. They have experienced it. This has helped me immensely. Secondly, many Quorans have listed invaluable resources, books and videos that do help you recover. I cannot overstate the importance of Quora in my healing process.
Healing from abuse tends to take a lot of time and energy. Reading questions and answers on Quora may be of some use but I hope you will also make a more concerted effort as well.
Quora essentially is a place to educate and feel heard. Healing comes in many different packages and it would be impossible to heal from Quora, alone.
